bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, [19--]

div1.p: LePrince reports on the effectiveness of the malaria control in railroad cars. LePrince also comments on the anti-malaria work in Georgia and Tennessee.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
FIELD HEADQUARTERS
ROOM 17, COURTHOUSE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
Dear Dr Carter
div1.p:
The soundness of your ideas
is showing up more & more- The Missouri
Pacific Ry, “Better Health Special” is proving a big
success & I was told last night that
the Ill. Cent. Ry sent their representative
to the exhibit cars (mostly malaria control exhibits)
& that he was very enthusiastic about the
exhibits & particularly about the way the
crowds collected at the train & the interest
they took in it- It looks very much as if
we shall soon have the I. C. Ry busy in their
territory also & they have recently acquired the
Gulf & Ship Island Ry also-.

The work in Shelby County Tenn is coming
on rapidly & Woodfall of Ga writes me they
are having more calls for help than
they can attend to in Georgia-

Parker is doing good work in
Northern Miss and has some good
2
men with him-.

I am following your original
plan of getting the business interests
to get proper perspective of things & the
bankers in Sumter Co Ga (near Americus)
are doing their own anti malaria
propaganda work-.

The Bankers Association of Little Rock
have a live wire agricultral representative
who has recently gone over to the Bankers
Assn of Ga & he wrote me he wants me to
help him as he is going to sell the
Malaria Control Idea to the Banking Interests
of Ga-.

There may be times when things
appear to move slowly but they are
coming now and you started something
that will rebuild the south when you
started off all alone back about 1912
to tackle the malaria problem single handed.

I know you will be glad to hear that most
all & all of the very recent county all time health units formed
are those where the antimalaria work was the
main sanitary work done-.
